content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Isabel Reyes: I was born and raised in San Francisco, though I didn't live in the same neighborhood my whole life. When I was 16, I was living in Pacific, but my family moved to a different part of the city—still in California, of course. I grew up in a tight-knit household with both of my parents, who were both college-educated and worked full-time. My father was a teacher, and my mother worked in healthcare. We were never wealthy, but we were comfortable, and that gave me a solid foundation. I always knew I wanted to go to college, partly because both of my parents had bachelor's degrees and valued education. I was a pretty quiet kid, but I loved reading and writing. I remember staying up late with my mom, who would read to me before bed, and that's where my love for stories began. I went to a public high school, and though I wasn't the most outgoing person, I had a few close friends and a supportive family. After high school, I attended a local university, where I studied literature. I always thought I'd end up teaching, but life had other plans. After college, I got married to my husband, who's a software developer, and we've been working to build a life together. We have two kids, and while it's been a busy few years, I still find time to read and write, which helps me feel grounded.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Isabel Reyes: Yes, there was a crossroads—actually, two of them. The first one was right after I graduated from college. I had been studying literature, and I thought I would follow in my father's footsteps and become a teacher. But during my senior year, I took a class in creative writing, and it completely changed my perspective. I realized I didn't just want to teach literature; I wanted to create it. I had always written stories as a child, but I never thought of it as a career. That class made me see that writing could be more than a hobby—it could be a way to express myself and connect with others. I had a chance to apply for a graduate program in creative writing, but I was hesitant because I didn't want to leave my husband, who was just starting his career. We had just gotten married, and we were building a life together. I remember sitting at the kitchen table, staring at the application, and feeling torn. On one hand, I felt like I was betraying my own dreams if I didn't go. On the other hand, I didn't want to uproot our family. In the end, I decided to stay in San Francisco and work a part-time job while writing on the side. It wasn't easy, but over time, I started getting published in small literary journals, and that gave me the confidence to keep going. The second crossroads came a few years later, when I was offered a full-time position as a writer for a local magazine. It was a huge opportunity, but it meant more travel and less time with my kids. Again, I had to weigh my personal life against my professional ambitions. This time, I chose to take the job, but I made sure to schedule my writing around my family's needs. Looking back, those moments taught me that life is full of choices, and sometimes the hardest ones are the ones that shape who you become.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Isabel Reyes: I think for me, it was a combination of both—conscious choices and moments that just happened. Like when I decided to stay in San Francisco after college, that was a deliberate choice, but the way my writing career unfolded after that felt more like a series of small, unexpected opportunities that added up. I remember submitting a short story to a local journal on a whim, and it got published. That gave me the confidence to keep going, even though I didn't have a plan. I think life is a mix of intention and serendipity. You make choices based on what you know at the time, but sometimes the path opens up in ways you never anticipated. I've learned to trust both the decisions I make and the moments that seem to come out of nowhere—they both shape who I am.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Isabel Reyes: Absolutely. I think having a mentor or someone who believed in me when I wasn't sure I believed in myself would have made a huge difference. Early on, when I was writing on the side, I didn't have much of a support system. My husband was incredibly supportive, but he was focused on his own career, and I didn't have a lot of friends who understood what I was trying to do. If there had been a writing group or a community center that offered workshops or classes, that might have given me the push I needed. I remember once attending a free writing workshop at a local library, and the instructor gave me some really helpful feedback. That single interaction made me realize I wasn't alone in my struggles, and it encouraged me to keep going. So yes, I think having access to resources or people who could offer guidance during those uncertain times would have helped me navigate those crossroads with more confidence.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Isabel Reyes: Yes, I have a partner and two children. My husband, Carlos, is a software developer, and we met in college—though we weren't together then. We reconnected a few years after graduation, and we've been married for over a decade now. He's been my biggest supporter, especially during the times when I was trying to find my voice as a writer. Our kids are 8 and 10, and they're both in local schools. They're very creative, just like me—my daughter loves drawing and writing stories, while my son is into robotics and coding. It's amazing to see them explore their own passions. Being a parent has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my life, but it's also been challenging. There are days when I feel like I'm juggling a million things at once, but I try to remind myself that it's all part of the journey. I wouldn't trade it for anything, even with the chaos.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by choices, support, and the unexpected. Starting from my childhood, where reading and writing were a comfort, to the crossroads I faced after college, each moment has led me to where I am today. I think it's important to recognize that while some decisions are made with intention, others come from the opportunities that find you when you least expect them. I'm grateful for the people in my life—especially my husband and children—who have supported me through it all. Their presence has been a constant, even as I've navigated the uncertainties of pursuing my passion for writing. It's a balance, but one I wouldn't trade for anything.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Isabel Reyes: My parents are still very much a part of our lives. They live in the same city, though a different neighborhood, and we see them often. My father retired from teaching a few years ago, and now he volunteers at a community center, which he absolutely loves. He's always been passionate about education, and it's heartwarming to see him give back in that way. My mother is still working part-time in healthcare, though she's more focused on being there for our family now. She's always been the one who encouraged me to follow my dreams, even when I wasn't sure what they were. I think I got my love for storytelling from her—she's an amazing listener and has a way of making everyone feel seen. We have a close relationship, and I know I can always count on them for support. My siblings, on the other hand, are spread out. My older brother lives in Seattle, and my younger sister is in New York. We don't get to see each other as often as I'd like, but we stay in touch through calls and visits. Family is really important to me, and I'm grateful for the ones I have, even when life gets busy.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Isabel Reyes: Yes, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Maria, who I met in college. She was in the same literature program as me, and we bonded over our love for books and writing. Even though we didn't end up in the same career paths, we've stayed close. She's a nurse now, but she's also an aspiring poet, and we often exchange poems and stories. She's been a great source of encouragement, especially when I was trying to find my way as a writer. Then there's Javier, who was my roommate during college. He's a musician, and he's always been the one to remind me to take a break and enjoy life. He's the kind of person who can make you laugh even on your worst days. I also have a few close friends from my writing group—though it's not an official group, we've formed a little community of writers who meet up occasionally to share our work and support each other. These people have been like family in many ways, offering advice, laughter, and sometimes just a listening ear when I needed it most.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Isabel Reyes: I live in a neighborhood called Pacific Heights, which is a bit upscale but still has that cozy, community feel. It's one of those places where you can walk to cafes, parks, and even a few bookstores. I love that there's a mix of old and new here—some of the buildings are historic, with beautiful architecture, while others are modern apartments with great amenities. The streets are quiet in the mornings, and there's always a sense of calm that comes with living near the water. I live in a two-story townhouse with my husband and kids. The house has a small garden where my daughter plants flowers, and my son has a little corner where he tinkers with his robotics projects. It's not huge, but it's perfect for our family. One of the things I appreciate most about this neighborhood is the sense of safety and the strong sense of community. We have a local library that hosts writing workshops, which I still attend sometimes, and there's a community center where my parents volunteer. It's a place where people look out for each other, and I feel really lucky to call it home.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Isabel Reyes: I feel very safe here, which is something I didn't always take for granted. When I was growing up in Pacific, it was a different time—there were more challenges, more uncertainty. But now, living in Pacific Heights, I can walk my kids to school without worrying, and I know the neighbors look out for one another. There's a kind of quiet confidence that comes with knowing you're in a place where people care about each other. It's not just about safety, though—it's about feeling seen and supported. I think that's why I love this neighborhood so much. It's not just a place to live; it's a place where I can be myself, and where my family can grow.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Isabel Reyes: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the sense of community I mentioned before—it makes all the difference, especially with two kids running around. There are days when I feel like I'm part of something bigger, like the neighborhood is almost a second family. But it's not without its challenges. The cost of living here is pretty high, and sometimes I worry about whether we're making the right financial choices for our future. I also miss the diversity of Pacific, where there were more cultural influences and a different rhythm to life. Still, I can't complain too much. The parks are beautiful, the schools are good, and there's always something happening—whether it's a local art show, a food festival, or just a quiet evening walk by the water. I think the key is finding balance. I love the peace and stability this neighborhood offers, but I also know that life is about growth, and I hope my kids will have the chance to experience different places too. For now, though, I'm grateful for where we are.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how much my sense of belonging is tied to the people and places around me. Talking about my husband, children, and parents brought up so many memories—like the quiet nights reading with my mom as a child, or the support my husband has given me as I've pursued writing. It's amazing how much my life has been shaped by the people I love. And when I described my neighborhood, I realized how much I value the safety, community, and opportunities it offers. It's not just a place to live; it's where my family grows, where I find inspiration, and where I feel truly at home. I'm grateful for all of it.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Isabel Reyes: A typical week for me is pretty full, but it has a rhythm that keeps things balanced. On weekdays, I usually wake up early, around 6:30, to get the kids ready for school. My husband and I take turns with the morning routine, and by 8:00, we're both out the door. I work from home most days as a freelance writer, which gives me the flexibility to manage my schedule around my kids' activities. Mondays and Wednesdays are usually my busiest days for writing, and I try to block off those hours so I can focus. Tuesdays and Thursdays are more about meetings and deadlines, and I often use the afternoons to pick up my daughter from after-school programs. Fridays are a bit more relaxed—my husband usually works from home on Fridays, so we have more time to spend together. We often go for a walk by the water or have a quiet dinner. Weekends are for family. We try to have a big breakfast on Saturdays, and then we might go to a park, a museum, or just have a movie day at home. Sundays are our day of rest, and we usually go to Mass together. It's not perfect, but this rhythm helps me feel grounded and connected to both my work and my family.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Isabel Reyes: I work as a freelance writer and editor, mostly from home, which gives me the flexibility to balance my career with my family life. My days usually start early, and I try to dedicate specific hours to writing and editing projects, whether it's working on articles for local magazines, editing content for small businesses, or even writing short stories on the side. I also do some part-time consulting for a nonprofit that focuses on literacy programs, which ties back to my love for education and storytelling. I work irregular hours, depending on deadlines, but I try to keep a routine so I can be present for my kids. Some weeks are busier than others, but I've learned to be adaptable. The best part is that I get to do something I truly enjoy, and I feel like I'm making a difference in small ways—whether it's helping someone tell their story or supporting a cause I believe in.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Isabel Reyes: Yes, there are a few other routines and responsibilities that I haven't mentioned. One of them is my weekly routine of volunteering at the local community center with my parents. I help out with literacy programs for kids who are struggling with reading, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's a way for me to give back, and it also gives my kids a chance to see the importance of helping others. I also make it a point to cook family dinners most nights, even if it's just simple meals. It's a way to slow down and connect with my family after a busy day. And of course, there's the bedtime routine with my kids—reading a story together before lights out. It's a small ritual, but it's something I look forward to every night. It reminds me of the quiet evenings with my mom when I was a child, and it's a way to pass on that love of stories to my own kids.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Isabel Reyes: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I've been trying to start the day with a few minutes of meditation or deep breathing, especially since the pace of life with two kids and a busy work schedule can get overwhelming. I found a short guided meditation app that my friend Maria recommended, and it's been a nice way to center myself before the chaos of the day begins. I also started taking short walks with my daughter before school, just to enjoy the quiet of the morning and get some fresh air. It's a small change, but it's made a big difference in how I feel throughout the day. I think it's important to carve out moments for yourself, even if they're brief, to stay grounded and present.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Isabel Reyes: My children have a pretty structured routine during the school year, especially on weekdays. They wake up around 7:00 a.m., and we have a quick breakfast together—usually something simple like toast, fruit, and juice. After that, they get ready for school, and by 7:45, they're out the door. My daughter is in third grade, and my son is in fifth. Both of them have after-school activities: my daughter joins a creative writing club at the community center twice a week, and my son is in a robotics club that meets on Mondays and Wednesdays. On the days they have these activities, I pick them up around 4:30 p.m., and we have a light snack before heading home. On days when they don't have activities, they often go to the library or a local park with friends. Once we're home, we have dinner together, and then it's time for homework, which they usually finish by 8:30 p.m. After that, we have our bedtime routine—reading a story together, and then lights out. It's a busy schedule, but I love seeing them engaged in things they're passionate about. It reminds me of how much I value creativity and learning, and I hope they carry that with them as they grow.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my sense of belonging is tied to the people and places in my life. Talking about my family reminded me of the quiet nights reading with my mom as a child and the unwavering support my husband has given me as I've pursued my writing. It's amazing how much my life has been shaped by the love and encouragement of those around me. When I described my neighborhood, I realized how much I value the safety, community, and opportunities it offers. It's not just a place to live—it's where my family grows, where I find inspiration, and where I feel truly at home. I'm grateful for all of it. Living here has its ups and downs, but the rhythm of my days, the routines I've built with my family, and the work I do as a writer and volunteer all contribute to a life that feels balanced and meaningful. Even small changes, like incorporating mindfulness into my mornings, remind me to stay present and grounded in the midst of it all.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Isabel Reyes: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty fortunate. I've always been active, even as a child—I loved walking with my mom to the park or playing in the backyard. Now, with two kids, I've found that keeping up with them keeps me on my feet, which is a good thing. I do try to maintain a healthy lifestyle—eating balanced meals, getting enough sleep when I can, and trying to stay consistent with exercise. I've started going for runs a few times a week, usually in the mornings before the kids wake up. It's not always easy, especially with the demands of work and family, but it helps me feel more centered. I also make sure to schedule regular check-ups with my doctor, and I've been lucky not to have any major health issues. That said, I've had my share of stress-related moments—like when I was juggling my writing career with parenting, or when I was dealing with the pressures of work deadlines. I've learned to take things one day at a time and to listen to my body when it needs rest. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I'm grateful for the health I have to be there for my family.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Isabel Reyes: What makes it easy to stay healthy is the rhythm of my days and the support of my family. My kids keep me moving, whether it's chasing them around the house or going for walks in the neighborhood. I also find that having a routine—like my morning runs or the family dinners—helps me stay grounded. But what makes it hard is the constant juggling act. There are days when I'm so caught up in work deadlines or family responsibilities that I neglect my own needs. I've learned to be more intentional about self-care, but it's still a challenge to find the time to prioritize it. I think the hardest part is knowing that I need to take care of myself so I can be there for my family, but sometimes I feel like I'm running on empty. It's a work in progress, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and remember that taking care of my health isn't just about me—it's about being the best version of myself for my kids and my work.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Isabel Reyes: In the past two years, I actually had a minor health issue that reminded me how important it is to listen to my body. A few months ago, I started experiencing some persistent back pain, which I initially dismissed as just the result of carrying my kids around or sitting at my desk for long hours while working. But one day, after a particularly busy week, I woke up with sharp pain radiating down my leg, and I realized it wasn't just strain—it was a sciatic nerve issue. I made an appointment with my doctor, and after some tests, I was diagnosed with a mild herniated disc. It wasn't anything too serious, but it did require me to take a few weeks off work to rest and recover. During that time, I had to rely on my husband to take over most of the household responsibilities, which was humbling but also a reminder of how much I depend on him. I started seeing a physical therapist, and I've been doing some exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture. It's been a slow process, but I'm feeling much better now. The experience also made me more aware of how stress and overexertion can take a toll on your body, and I've been more mindful about pacing myself and taking breaks when I need to.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Isabel Reyes: It was definitely challenging at first. I had to adjust to a slower pace, which was hard because I'm used to being productive all the time. There were days when I felt frustrated or even a little helpless, especially when I couldn't do the things I normally do—like picking up my kids from school or working on my writing. But honestly, it also gave me a chance to slow down and reconnect with my family in a way I hadn't before. My husband took on more responsibilities, and I found myself doing more of the things I used to put off, like cooking meals together or just sitting down for a quiet conversation. It reminded me that sometimes, when life throws you a curveball, it's not just about getting back to where you were—it's about finding new ways to move forward. I'm still recovering, but I've learned that taking care of myself isn't just about being strong; it's also about knowing when to ask for help and when to rest.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Isabel Reyes: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel deeply grateful, and others I feel the weight of everything I'm juggling. There's been a lot of growth, both personally and as a parent. I've learned to be more present, to slow down and really listen to my kids when they talk about their day, or even when they're just being silly. I've also found more peace in my writing, even if it's not as consistent as I'd like. There were moments when I felt overwhelmed, especially during the pandemic surge, when schools were closed and everything felt uncertain. But I also felt a deep sense of connection with my family, knowing we were all in this together. I think the past year has taught me that resilience isn't about being unshakable—it's about finding small ways to keep going, even when things feel heavy. I'm still learning, but I feel more grounded than I have in a long time.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and well-being are intertwined with the rhythm of my daily life and the support of my family. Talking about my recent changes, like incorporating mindfulness into my mornings, reminded me of how small, intentional moments can make a big difference in staying grounded. When I shared about my health struggles with the herniated disc, it brought up how vulnerable it can feel to slow down and rely on others, but also how important it is to take care of myself so I can be there for my family. Reflecting on what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy, I realized that while my family and routines help me stay on track, the constant juggling of work and parenting can make it challenging to prioritize my own needs. It's a reminder that health isn't just about physical well-being—it's also about balance, self-compassion, and knowing when to ask for help. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the lessons these experiences have taught me about resilience and care.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Isabel Reyes: Honestly, I've had moments where I've felt the weight of anxiety, especially during the pandemic when everything felt so uncertain. There were days when I would wake up feeling like I wasn't enough—like I wasn't doing enough for my family, my work, or even for myself. I remember one particular time when I was juggling a big writing project, my kids' schoolwork, and my health recovery all at once, and I felt like I was drowning in responsibilities. I didn't want to talk about it with anyone because I didn't want to burden them, but I realized I needed to find a way to take care of my mental health, too. I started talking to a therapist, which was a big step for me. It helped me understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and that I don't have to be perfect to be present for the people I love. I still have days when anxiety creeps in, but I've learned to recognize it and respond with kindness instead of judgment. I think the most important thing is that I'm not alone in feeling this way, and I'm learning to ask for help when I need it.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Isabel Reyes: For my family, it's been a year of adjustment and deepening connections. My husband has been incredibly patient and supportive, especially during my recovery from the herniated disc. He's taken on more of the household responsibilities, and I've learned to appreciate how much he does behind the scenes. Our kids have also grown a lot—they've become more independent, and I see how they're starting to take on little responsibilities, like helping with dinner or organizing their school supplies. It's been bittersweet, though. There were moments when I felt like I wasn't there for them as much as I wanted to be, especially during the pandemic when everything was so uncertain. But I think what we've gained is a stronger sense of unity. We've learned to lean on each other more, to communicate better, and to find joy in the little things. Even when life feels overwhelming, I know I have a family that loves me and supports me, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Isabel Reyes: For me, religion has always been a grounding force, especially growing up Catholic. My mother was the one who really instilled that in me—those quiet evenings reading the Bible before bed, the Sunday Masses we attended as a family, the way she would explain the stories and values behind them. Even now, as an adult, I find comfort in my faith. It's not just about following the rules or going to church every week—it's about the sense of community, the rituals that connect me to something bigger than myself. I still go to Mass regularly, and it's a time when I can step back from the chaos of daily life and just be present. I also find solace in prayer, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed or uncertain. It's not always easy to maintain that connection, especially with the demands of work and family, but I try to make it a priority. I think faith has helped me through some of the hardest moments in my life, like when I was dealing with my health issues or feeling like I wasn't enough for my family. It reminds me that I'm not alone, and that there's always hope, even when things feel impossible.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Isabel Reyes: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that it can be both a connection and a distraction, and I've learned to be selective about how I engage with it. I do follow a few local writers and artists on Instagram, mostly because their work inspires me. I also have a small group of friends from college who keep in touch through Facebook, and I enjoy seeing updates about their lives, especially since we don't get to see each other as often as I'd like. That said, I tend to limit my time online, especially during the week, because I want to be fully present for my kids and my writing. There are days when I feel like I'm missing out on something, but I've come to realize that my life is already full in ways that social media can't replicate. I prefer face-to-face conversations or even a phone call over scrolling through posts. It's not that I don't value staying connected—it's just that I've found my own way of doing it, one that feels more meaningful to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Isabel Reyes: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, the support has always come from the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and even my community. When I was going through my health issues, it was my husband who held things together, and my parents who reminded me that I wasn't alone. I do think there's value in online communities, especially for people who might not have that kind of support system nearby. I just haven't found myself in that situation. What I have found is that sometimes, the most meaningful support comes from the quiet moments—like when my daughter tucks me in at night with a story she wrote, or when my husband brings me a cup of tea after a long day. Those are the things that really help me feel grounded.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how deeply my health and mental well-being are connected to the balance I try to maintain in my life. Talking about my herniated disc reminded me of how fragile our bodies can be and how important it is to listen to them when they send signals that something is wrong. It also brought up the emotional weight of having to slow down and rely on others, which was humbling but also a reminder of how much I depend on my family's support. When I shared about my struggles with anxiety, it felt like a weight was lifted just by acknowledging it, and it reminded me that it's okay not to be okay all the time. I realized that my mental health is just as important as my physical health, and that asking for help—whether from a therapist or from my loved ones—is a sign of strength, not weakness. These conversations have helped me see that healing is not just about fixing what's broken, but also about learning to be kinder to myself and finding ways to move forward with more grace and understanding.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Isabel Reyes: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted—there are still days when I feel the weight of everything, but I've also found new ways to cope. One of the biggest changes has been how I approach my anxiety. Instead of trying to push it away, I've started acknowledging it and giving myself permission to feel it. I've taken up journaling again, something I used to do as a child, and it's been a great way to process my thoughts and emotions. I also try to practice mindfulness more consistently now, even if it's just a few deep breaths before I start my day. I've learned that it's okay not to have all the answers, and that self-compassion is just as important as pushing forward. My emotional coping strategies have evolved, and I'm more aware of how my mental health affects everything else in my life. I'm still learning, but I feel more equipped to handle the ups and downs now than I did before.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Isabel Reyes: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to housing, childcare, and healthcare. Rent for our townhouse in Pacific Heights is pretty high, especially with the cost of living here, so that's a significant chunk of our budget. Then there's the childcare—both of my kids are in after-school programs, and we also hire a part-time babysitter a couple of times a week when we need extra help. Healthcare costs have also been a factor, especially since I've been seeing a physical therapist for my herniated disc. I also have health insurance through my freelance work, but the premiums and copays add up. On top of that, we have regular expenses like groceries, utilities, and transportation. I try to budget carefully, and we've been pretty good about sticking to our plan, but it's always a balancing act. I'm grateful that we've managed to save a little each month, which gives us some peace of mind for the future.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Isabel Reyes: Our household spent around $6,500 last month, which is actually a bit more than usual. Typically, we hover around $6,000 to $6,200, depending on the month. The increase this time was mostly due to an unexpected repair on our townhouse's plumbing system—something we hadn't budgeted for. Other than that, our usual expenses are pretty consistent: rent is about $2,500, childcare and after-school programs run around $1,200, and healthcare, including my physical therapy sessions, comes to roughly $800. Groceries are another $800 to $1,000, and we spend about $500 on utilities and transportation. We also set aside a small amount each month for savings, which has been a priority for us since we want to ensure we're financially stable for our kids' future. It's not always easy, but we've learned to be flexible and make choices that align with our values, even if it means cutting back on non-essentials now and then.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Isabel Reyes: We rent our home. It's a two-story townhouse in Pacific Heights, and while it's not owned by us, it feels like home in every way that matters. Renting has its pros and cons—on one hand, it gives us flexibility, especially since my work as a freelance writer can be unpredictable at times. On the other hand, the cost is definitely a challenge. I think we've come to terms with the fact that renting is the practical choice for now, especially with the way the real estate market is in San Francisco. We've been here for about six years, and while I've considered buying, the prices are just too high for us to feel comfortable making that leap. For now, we're focused on saving and making sure we're in a stable financial position for our kids' future. Renting allows us to stay in a neighborhood we love without the long-term commitment of a mortgage, and I think that's a smart decision for our family right now.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Isabel Reyes: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, depending on the season and what's going on with the kids. For example, during the school year, our childcare and after-school program costs are pretty consistent, but when school is out, we end up spending more on summer camps and activities to keep the kids occupied. Then there's the holiday season—December is always the most expensive month because of gifts, holiday meals, and the extra electricity usage from heating the house. We also had a big spike in our utility bills last winter when we had to replace the old heating system in the townhouse, which wasn't covered by our insurance. On the flip side, summer tends to be a bit cheaper because we use less electricity for heating, and we sometimes save money by doing more activities at home. I've learned to track our expenses more closely, especially around these seasonal changes, and it's helped us adjust our budget accordingly. It's not perfect, but it's given us a better sense of how to plan ahead and stay on top of things without getting overwhelmed.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and faith have supported me through the challenges of the past year. Talking about my health struggles reminded me of how much I rely on my husband and how grateful I am for his patience and strength during my recovery. It also brought up how my children have grown in ways I hadn't anticipated, becoming more independent and thoughtful. When I discussed my faith, I realized how much it continues to be a source of comfort and grounding, especially during moments of doubt or anxiety. And when I shared how I don't use social media much, it reminded me that the most meaningful connections in my life are the ones I've built in person—whether with my family, friends, or the community around me. These conversations have helped me see that even in the midst of uncertainty, I have a strong foundation of love, support, and belief that carries me forward.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Isabel Reyes: I do save, and it's something I've made a priority for our family. We have a dedicated savings account that we contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. It's not always easy, especially with the way our expenses can fluctuate, but I've learned that consistency matters more than the amount. We also have a separate emergency fund that we've been building over the years, which has been a lifesaver, especially when unexpected things like the plumbing repair came up. I think saving is about more than just money—it's about creating a sense of security for my kids and for us as a family. It's not always perfect, and there are months when we have to adjust, but I believe in the value of planning ahead. I also try to teach my kids about saving, even in small ways, like setting aside a portion of their allowance for something they want. It's a lesson I hope they carry with them as they grow.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Isabel Reyes: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals, like my kids' future. We've been contributing to our emergency fund regularly, which has been crucial, especially with unexpected expenses like the plumbing repair we had earlier this year. But I've also been thinking more about saving for their education—maybe a college fund or something similar. I know it's still a ways off, but I want to start early so they have options. I also save a little each month for personal goals, like taking a writing workshop or attending a conference. It's not about big splurges for me; it's more about creating a sense of stability and opportunity for my family. I think saving is a way of showing my kids that planning and responsibility matter, even in small ways. It's not always easy, but it's something I believe in deeply.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Isabel Reyes: My occupation has been a bit of an evolving journey. I started as a freelance writer and editor, which allows me to work from home and have a flexible schedule—something that's been really important for balancing my family life. My main duties involve writing articles, editing content for small businesses, and occasionally working on creative projects like short stories or essays. I also do some part-time consulting for a nonprofit focused on literacy programs, which ties back to my love for education and storytelling. One of the most important aspects of my work is the ability to tell stories that matter, whether it's helping a local business share its mission or supporting a cause I believe in. I also enjoy the creative freedom that comes with being a writer, even though it can be unpredictable at times. Over the years, I've learned to embrace the flexibility and find ways to make my work sustainable while still being present for my family. It's not always easy, but I feel lucky to be doing something I truly enjoy.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Isabel Reyes: I usually work around 30 to 35 hours a week, but it varies depending on deadlines and projects. Some weeks are busier, especially when I'm working on a big article or editing a magazine piece, and other weeks are more relaxed. The beauty of being a freelance writer is that I can adjust my hours based on what's needed, but I also have to be disciplined to make sure I'm productive. I try to set a schedule for myself, even if it's not the same every day. Most of my work happens in the mornings, when the house is quiet and my kids are still asleep. I find that time to be the most focused. In the afternoons, I handle emails, meetings, and any client communication. On days when I'm not working, I use that time to recharge—whether it's reading, going for a walk, or just spending time with my family. It's not always perfect, but I've learned to balance my work with the rest of my life in a way that feels sustainable.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Isabel Reyes: Yes, I actually have a few different streams of work that I juggle, though they're all related to writing and education in some way. In addition to my freelance writing and editing, I also run a small online course for aspiring writers, which I developed a few years ago. It's something I do part-time, usually in the evenings or on weekends, and it's been a nice way to share what I've learned with others. I also volunteer with a literacy nonprofit a few hours a week, which allows me to give back to the community and support kids who are struggling with reading. It's not always easy to manage all of these things at once, but I've found that having a variety of work helps keep me engaged and prevents burnout. Plus, it gives me a sense of purpose beyond just making a living—it's about contributing in ways that matter to me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Isabel Reyes: In total, our household made around $7,200 in the past month. That includes my freelance writing income, the small earnings from my online writing course, and the stipend I receive from the nonprofit I volunteer with. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our expenses and still set aside some money for savings. I've learned that income can be a bit unpredictable, especially with freelance work, but I try to plan ahead as much as possible. It's also comforting to know that I'm not just working for money—I'm doing something I love, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Isabel Reyes: I don't have a single workplace in the traditional sense, since I work from home as a freelance writer and editor. But I do have a small office space in our townhouse that I've set up to be my workspace. It's not much—just a desk, a couple of bookshelves, and a comfortable chair—but it's my sanctuary. I've been working this way for about six years now, ever since I decided to leave the idea of a traditional 9-to-5 job behind. The benefits of this kind of work are both practical and personal. On the practical side, I have health insurance through a small business plan I set up, which covers me and my family. I also have the flexibility to take time off when I need to, whether it's for a sick day, a vacation, or just a day to recharge. I don't get paid time off in the traditional sense, but I've learned to build that into my schedule. On the personal side, the biggest benefit is being able to be present for my kids and my family. I can pick them up from school, help with homework, and still get my work done. It's not always easy, but I've found a rhythm that works for us. I think the biggest challenge is the lack of structure, but I've learned to create my own structure through routines and planning. It's not perfect, but it's a life that feels meaningful and balanced to me.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Isabel Reyes: Since I work freelance, I don't have a traditional manager or boss, which is both liberating and a bit isolating at times. My relationships with clients are usually professional but also collaborative—I often have ongoing projects with a few regular clients, and we build a kind of rapport over time. I enjoy the independence it gives me, but I'll admit there are days when I miss the structure of having coworkers to bounce ideas off of or just chat with during the day. That's why I've made an effort to connect with other writers in the community, whether through workshops, online groups, or even just coffee meetups. It's not the same as having a traditional office environment, but it helps me feel less alone in my work. I think the biggest thing is that I've learned to be my own manager, setting goals, meeting deadlines, and holding myself accountable. It's a different kind of relationship with work, but one that I've come to appreciate for the freedom and flexibility it offers.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Isabel Reyes: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is both a blessing and a challenge. On one hand, I love that I can set my own hours and work around my kids' schedules. For example, I often start my day early, around 6:30 a.m., when the house is quiet, and I can focus on writing without interruptions. But I also have to be disciplined about setting boundaries, because it's easy to work late into the night or take on too much at once. Some days, I might have a full day of writing and editing, while other days I might only work a few hours if I'm juggling family responsibilities or need to rest. The flexibility is great for my family life, but it does mean I have to be proactive about managing my time and staying on top of deadlines. I've learned to use tools like calendars and to-do lists to keep things organized, and I try to block out specific times for work, family, and self-care. It's not always perfect, but it's a system that works for me and helps me stay balanced.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Isabel Reyes: Overall, I feel pretty stable about our financial situation, though there are definitely moments when I worry about the future. We've managed to build a life that's comfortable for our family, and I'm grateful for that. I know we're not wealthy, but we're not struggling either, and that gives me a sense of security. What I value most is the fact that we're able to provide for our kids' needs and give them opportunities—like their after-school programs, their books, and the chance to explore their interests. I also appreciate that we've been able to save a little each month, even if it's not a lot. It's not always easy to balance everything—work, family, and financial responsibilities—but I feel like we're on the right path. I think the most important thing is that we're making choices that align with our values, and that gives me peace of mind, even when things feel uncertain.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Isabel Reyes: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a teacher, and he worked full-time at a local high school for over twenty years. My mother worked in healthcare, first as a nurse and later in administrative roles at a hospital. They both had stable jobs that allowed us to live comfortably, and they always made it a priority to support my education. I remember my father coming home exhausted after long days of teaching, but he still made time to read with me before bed. My mother, on the other hand, was always juggling work and family responsibilities, but she never let me feel like I was a burden. I think their dedication to their jobs and their families is what shaped me into the person I am today—someone who values hard work, education, and the importance of supporting those you love.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Isabel Reyes: My father was a high school teacher, and his most important activities involved not just teaching subjects like literature and history, but also mentoring his students and helping them find their voices. He had a way of making even the most reluctant student feel seen and valued. I remember how he would stay after class to talk to kids who were struggling, whether it was with schoolwork or personal issues. He believed that education was more than just books and tests—it was about opening minds and inspiring young people to dream bigger. My mother worked as a nurse for many years, and her most important duties were caring for patients, listening to their stories, and providing comfort during difficult times. She had a deep sense of empathy, and I think that's where I got my love for storytelling. Even now, when I write, I try to capture the same kind of compassion and connection that my mother showed in her work. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made time for their family, and that taught me the importance of balance, dedication, and love.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Isabel Reyes: My father worked at a local high school in San Francisco, and my mother was employed at a hospital in the same city. My father's job was more than just teaching—he was a mentor, a guide, and sometimes even a friend to his students. He taught literature and history, but he also made sure his students felt heard and understood. He would often stay late after school to help kids with their assignments or just to talk about their dreams. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a nurse in the hospital's emergency department for many years. She was the kind of person who could calm a frightened patient with just a smile or a gentle touch. Her job was demanding, but she always found a way to give her best to both her patients and her family. I think what I learned from them both was that work is not just about earning a living—it's about making a difference, even in small ways. They both gave so much of themselves to their jobs, and I try to carry that same sense of purpose in everything I do today.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Isabel Reyes: I hope that in a few years, I'm still writing, still finding joy in stories, and still being present for my family. I hope my kids are growing into confident, compassionate people who know the value of education, creativity, and kindness. I hope we're still living in Pacific Heights, or maybe even in a different neighborhood that feels just as welcoming and full of life. I hope I'm still volunteering with the literacy programs, still learning, and still growing as a person. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with moments that make me feel grateful—like the quiet mornings with my daughter, the laughter of my son, the support of my husband, and the stories I get to tell. I hope I'm still learning to balance everything, and that I'm still finding ways to be kind to myself and others, even when life gets messy. Most of all, I hope I'm still here, still loving, and still writing.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Isabel Reyes: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the ones who have been with me through every chapter, from the quiet nights reading with my mother as a child to the moments of uncertainty and growth as an adult. I value my family above all else, because they are the foundation of everything I do. I also value the stories we tell—both the ones we share with each other and the ones I get to write. There's something deeply meaningful about connecting with others through words, whether it's a story that helps someone feel seen or a poem that captures a moment of joy. I value the balance I try to maintain between my work, my family, and my own well-being, even when it's not perfect. And I value the sense of belonging I feel in this neighborhood, where I can walk to the library, hear the laughter of children playing in the park, and know that I'm part of something bigger than myself. Life is full of challenges, but it's also full of love, and that's what I hold onto most.
